undefined In past generations he allowed all the nations to go their own ways,

undefined So they were sent on their way by the church, and as they passed through both Phoenicia and Samaria, they were relating at length the conversion of the Gentiles and bringing great joy to all the brothers.

undefined Both the apostles and the elders met together to deliberate about this matter.

undefined and he made no distinction between them and us, cleansing their hearts by faith.
undefined So now why are you putting God to the test by placing on the neck of the disciples a yoke that neither our ancestors nor we have been able to bear?
undefined On the contrary, we believe that we are saved through the grace of the Lord Jesus, in the same way as they are.”

undefined She fol-lowed behind Paul and us and kept crying out, “These men are servants of the Most High God, who are proclaiming to you the way of salvation.”

undefined She continued to do this for many days. But Paul became greatly annoyed, and turned and said to the spirit, “I command you in the name of Jesus Christ to come out of her!” And it came out of her at once.

undefined This went on for two years, so that all who lived in the province of Asia, both Jews and Greeks, heard the word of the Lord.The Seven Sons of Sceva
undefined God was performing extraordinary miracles by Paul’s hands,

undefined But some itinerant Jewish exor-cists tried to invoke the name of the Lord Je-sus over those who were possessed by evil spirits, saying, “I sternly warn you by Jesus whom Paul preaches.”
undefined (Now seven sons of a man named Sceva, a Jewish high priest, were doing this.)
undefined But the evil spirit re-plied to them, “I know about Jesus and I am acquainted with Paul, but who are you?”
undefined Then the man who was possessed by the evil spirit jumped on them and beat them all into submission. He prevailed against them so that they fled from that house naked and wound-ed.

undefined Many of those who had believed came forward, confessing and mak-ing their deeds known.

undefined Large numbers of those who had practiced magic collected their books and burned them up in the presence of everyone. When the value of the books was added up, it was found to total fifty thousand silver coins.
undefined In this way the word of the Lord continued to grow in power and to pre-vail.A Riot in Ephesus
undefined Now after all these things had taken place, Paul resolved to go to Jerusalem, pass-ing through Macedonia and Achaia. He said, “After I have been there, I must also see Rome.”

undefined He gath-ered these together, along with the workmen in similar trades, and said, “Men, you know that our prosperity comes from this business.

undefined And you see and hear that this Paul has persuaded and turned away a large crowd, not only in Ephesus but in practically all of the province of Asia, by saying that gods made by hands are not gods at all.

undefined When they heard this they became enraged and began to shout, “Great is Artemis of the Ephesians!”
undefined The city was filled with the uproar, and the crowd rushed to the theater together, dragging with them Gaius and Aristarchus, the Macedonians who were Paul’s traveling companions.
undefined But when Paul wanted to enter the public assembly, the disciples would not let him.

undefined For you have brought these men here who are neither temple robbers nor blasphemers of our goddess.
undefined If then Demetrius and the craftsmen who are with him have a complaint against someone, the courts are open and there are proconsuls; let them bring charges against one another there.
undefined But if you want any-thing in addition, it will have to be settled in a legal assembly.
undefined For we are in danger of being charged with rioting today, since there is no cause we can give to explain this disorderly gathering.”
undefined After he had said this, he dismissed the assembly.Paul Travels Through Macedonia and Greece
After the disturbance had ended, Paul sent for the disciples, and after encouraging them and saying farewell, he left to go to Macedonia.
undefined After he had gone through those regions and spoken many words of en-couragement to the believers there, he came to Greece,
undefined where he stayed for three months. Because the Jews had made a plot against him as he was intending to sail for Syria, he decid-ed to return through Macedonia.

undefined Paul was accompanied by Sopater son of Pyrrhus from Berea, Aristarchus and Secundus from Thessa-lonica, Gaius from Derbe, and Timothy, as well as Tychicus and Trophimus from the province of Asia.
undefined These had gone on ahead and were waiting for us in Troas.
undefined We sailed away from Philippi after the days of Unleavened Bread, and within five days we came to the others in Troas, where we stayed for seven days.
undefined On the first day of the week, when we met to break bread, Paul be-gan to speak to the people, and because he intended to leave the next day, he extended his message until midnight.
undefined (Now there were many lamps in the upstairs room where we were meeting.)

undefined A young man named Eutychus, who was sitting in the window, was sinking into a deep sleep while Paul continued to speak for a long time. Fast asleep, he fell down from the third story and was picked up dead.
undefined But Paul went down, threw him-self on the young man, put his arms around him, and said, “Do not be distressed, for he is still alive!”
undefined Then Paul went back upstairs, and after he had broken bread and eaten, he talked with them a long time, until dawn. Then he left.
undefined They took the boy home alive and were greatly comforted.The Voyage to Miletus
undefined We went on ahead to the ship and put out to sea for Assos, intending to take Paul aboard there, for he had arranged it this way. He himself was intending to go there by land.
undefined When he met us in Assos, we took him aboard and went to Mitylene.
undefined We set sail from there, and on the following day we ar-rived off Chios. The next day we approached Samos, and the day after that we arrived at Miletus.
undefined For Paul had decided to sail past Ephesus so as not to spend time in the province of Asia, for he was hurrying to arrive in Jerusalem, if possible, by the day of Pente-cost.
undefined From Miletus he sent a message to Ephesus, telling the elders of the church to come to him.
undefined When they arrived, he said to them, “You yourselves know how I lived the whole time I was with you, from the first day I set foot in the province of Asia,
undefined serving the Lord with all humility and with tears, and with the trials that happened to me because of the plots of the Jews.
undefined You know that I did not hold back from proclaiming to you any-thing that would be helpful, and from teaching you publicly and from house to house,
undefined testifying to both Jews and Greeks about re-pentance toward God and faith in our Lord Jesus.
undefined And now, compelled by the Spirit, I am going to Jerusalem without knowing what will happen to me there,
undefined except that the Holy Spirit warns me in town after town that imprisonment and persecutions are waiting for me.
undefined But I do not consider my life worth anything to myself, so that I may finish my task and the ministry that I received from the Lord Jesus, to testify to the good news of God’s grace.
undefined “And now I know that none of you among whom I went around proclaiming the kingdom will see me again.
undefined Therefore I declare to you today that I am innocent of the blood of you all.
undefined For I did not hold back from announcing to you the whole purpose of God.
undefined Watch out for yourselves and for all the flock of which the Holy Spirit has made you overseers, to shepherd the church of God that he obtained with the blood of his own Son.
undefined I know that after I am gone fierce wolves will come in among you, not sparing the flock.
undefined Even from among your own group men will arise, teaching perversions of the truth to draw the disciples away after them.

undefined And now I entrust you to God and to the mes-sage of his grace. This message is able to build you up and give you an inheritance among all those who are sanctified.
undefined I have desired no one’s silver or gold or clothing.
undefined You yourselves know that these hands of mine provided for my needs and the needs of those who were with me.

undefined By all these things, I have shown you that by working in this way we must help the weak, and remember the words of the Lord Jesus that he himself said, ‘It is more blessed to give than to receive.’”
undefined When he had said these things, he knelt down with them all and prayed.
undefined They all began to weep loudly, and hugged Paul and kissed him,
undefined especially saddened by what he had said, that they were not going to see him again. Then they accompanied him to the ship.Paul’s Journey to Jerusalem
After we tore ourselves away from them, we put out to sea, and sailing a straight course, we came to Cos, on the next day to Rhodes, and from there to Patara.
undefined We found a ship crossing over to Phoenicia, went aboard, and put out to sea.
undefined After we sighted Cyprus and left it behind on our port side, we sailed on to Syria and put in at Tyre, because the ship was to unload its cargo there.
undefined After we located the disciples, we stayed there seven days. They repeatedly told Paul through the Spirit not to set foot in Jerusalem.
